notEnoughChars: You must enter at least @chars characters!

taskDescription:
De Morgan’s Law for the complement of the intersection of two sets <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mi>A</mi>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">A</annotation></semantics></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mi>B</mi>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">B</annotation></semantics></math> states that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <mo stretchy="false">(</mo>
    <mi>A</mi>
    <mo>∩<!-- ∩ --></mo>
    <mi>B</mi>
    <msup>
      <mo stretchy="false">)</mo>
      <mi class="MJX-variant" mathvariant="normal">′<!-- ′ --></mi>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
  <mo>=</mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mi>A</mi>
      <mi class="MJX-variant" mathvariant="normal">′<!-- ′ --></mi>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
  <mo>∪<!-- ∪ --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mi>B</mi>
      <mi class="MJX-variant" mathvariant="normal">′<!-- ′ --></mi>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">{(A \cap B)^\prime } = {A^\prime } \cup {B^\prime }</annotation></semantics></math>. Use a Venn diagram to prove that De Morgan’s Law is true.
